Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Management and Opportunistic Usage of Radio Spectrum based Graph Theory
Award.AbstractNarration: The tremendous increasing demand to support various data applications requires a wireless network to be more agile and spectral-efficient. Cognitive Radio technology allows secondary users to access the underutilized licensed bands and is a promising solution. However, the coexistence of secondary users with the authorized primary users requires careful and dynamic resource management to deal with interference, which is a very challenging issue. The major objective of this project is to deal with the issue by utilizing graph theory/algorithms to develop efficient resource management schemes for general coexistence scenarios.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of the NSF grant, we have investigated various graph-based algorithms for wireless communication design, and have achieved fruitful research findings. In total, we have published/submitted 8 journal papers and 8 conference papers. We have given presentations at IEEE conferences. We have created a website for public access of our research findings.

Our research findings cover broad areas of wireless communications and graph theory, especially the joint areas. In specific, We investigate resource allocation problems based on graph theory by taking users’ preferences into account. Algorithms based on stable-matching are utilized. We then modified graph-based algorithms to improve the robustness of the proposed algorithms to channel information change. At last, we study path selection and power allocation problems for relay-aided wireless communication systems. We consider the scenario that the source node can be paired with any destination node and the scenario that each source node has its targeted destination node. We propose graph-based solutions to take fairness among different links into account. We also apply the graph-based algorithms to the \emph{Device-to-device} (D2D) communications, which is another potential application scenario to improve spectral efficiency.

Our research contributes to both wireless communication society and graph theory. It will help others to explore more in related areas.
